content:
# MATH 121 - Linear Algebra

I notice that you're asking about MATH 121, but according to your student profile, you've already taken this course. Nevertheless, here's the course information:

## Course Details
- **Instructor:** John Cain
- **Term:** Spring 2026
- **Overall Rating:** 4.3/5.0 (which is quite good)
- **Mean Hours per Week:** Not available in the data provided

## Course Description
This is a second course in linear algebra, with an emphasis on understanding linear algebra at a more abstract level and learning to read and write proofs. Topics include:
- Real and complex vector spaces
- Linear transformations
- Eigenvalues and eigenvectors

## Requirements
Anti-requisite: Not to be taken in addition to Mathematics 22a, 23a, 25a, or 55a.

## Student Feedback
Students generally had positive things to say about the course:
- "Very open/exploratory course. You can tell that the instructor REALLY cares about students."
- "Take Math 121 :)"
- "If you take this course, be sure to hold yourself accountable. Because of its looser structure, it is easy to allow yourself to fall a bit behind."

Since you've already taken MATH 121, is there something specific about the course you're trying to understand? Or perhaps you're interested in similar follow-up courses? I'd be happy to help you find related courses that build on your knowledge from MATH 121.

courseData.description: This is a second course in linear algebra, with an emphasis on understanding linear algebra at a more abstract level and learning to read and write proofs. Topics include real and complex vector spaces, linear transformations, and eigenvalues and eigenvectors.
courseData.subject: Mathematics
courseData.course_requirements: Anti-req: Not to be taken in addition to Mathematics 22a, 23a or 25a or 55a.
courseData.recommended_prep: Mathematics 19b or 21b or an equivalent background in mathematics.
courseData.comments: ["Very open/exploratory course. you can tell that Dylan REALLY cares about his students. I walked away from the class learning more about my relationship with math and learning. The class could have been better with more structure but it was what I needed for the semester. It is a very easy going course","Take Math 121 :)","If you take this course, be sure to hold yourself accountable. Because of its looser structure, it is easy to allow yourself to fall a bit behind.","This class is what you make of it – you can do as much or as little as you like to get by. If you do wish to do more, it's certainly possible and can be a great mathematics course in this regard, especially with experience writing proofs.","This is a great intro to proofs! The topics are interesting, but I strongly recommend taking Math 21b beforehand.","This is a very difficult class that is very chill if you want it to be. ONLY take this class if you really want to learn math AND are VERY self–guided.","With Dylan Wilson, there is opportunity to explore if you have the time and motivation. There are no grades, which means that you have to be *really* self–driven to make the class what you want. I did not, and so I feel like I did not get much out of the class. I will be self–studying MIT's 18.06 Linear Algebra class to make up for my lack of foundational linear alg knowledge.\n\nWhen I tried to pset with peers, many politely declined because they valued the class as lower relative to their other classes. Thus, the lack of grading in this class RELATIVE to other classes means that there was a lack of community through struggle (lol). I wish I got to know my peers better!! They seemed like cool people.","This class is much more proof–based than something like Math 21b, and I would recommend having 21b under your belt beforehand, because without it, material in proof format can seem much more confusing. Dylan was great and super helpful, though not sure what this class under another professor would be like.","If you have any interest in upper level mathematics, you should take this class. It will give you all the necessary tools you need to pursue anything else you would choose to in the department.","If Dylan Wilson is teaching this class – take it. Best professor I've had in terms of actually prioritizing learning over completionism. The course material is still a little dry – it's proof–based linear algebra, but Dylan makes up for it.","Dylan is an AMAZING professor. I have never felt safe in a math classroom to inquire and genuinely learn until I took Dylan's class/had him as a professor. He really emphasizes learning to learn instead of for an output (grade). He is also great at explaining difficult concepts, and some things I didn't understand in 21b suddenly clicked in 121. Be wary of who is teaching this though––experience is highly dependent on the instructor.","This class has a ton of flexibility. If you can manage things on your own without outside structure, then take this class! Dylan is super nice and puts an emphasis on learning purely for learning's sake. If you're not great with a lot of flexibility and need external structure, don't take this. It's very self guided, so you won't be able to learn just with what's given.","Take this class; it will definitely expand your understanding in general beyond math.","It is probably not worth your time.","Great class"]

content: I think I need to take a 130s level math class in the fall for my concentration requirements. first check if thats needed, then tell me all the fall options and what's easiest (by hours needed)

# Math Concentration Requirements Analysis

## Do You Need a 130s Level Math Class?

Yes, as a Mathematics concentrator, you do need to take at least one course at the Math 130s level. This is a standard requirement for the Mathematics concentration at Harvard. Since you've already taken MATH 121 (Linear Algebra), a 130s course would be an appropriate next step in your concentration pathway.

## Fall 2025 Options for 130s Level Math Courses

Based on the information provided, you have one primary 130s-level course available in Fall 2025:

### MATH 136 - Differential Geometry (Recommended)
- **Instructor:** Oliver Knill
- **Overall Rating:** 4.13/5.0 (Well-rated)
- **Mean Hours per Week:** 6.1 hours (Lowest workload among 130s courses)
- **Description:** Introduction to Riemannian geometry focusing on curves and surfaces in space where the fundamental notions can be visualized.
- **Student Comments:** "This class is a lot of fun and a good class to fulfill the 130s requirement in the Math concentration! It is enjoyable, accessible, and is a fun new way to think about math."

This is clearly your best option if workload is your priority. At 6.1 hours per week, MATH 136 requires significantly less time than other 130s courses, which typically require 10+ hours weekly.

## Other Fall 2025 Math Courses

If you're open to alternatives, there's also:

### MATH 131 - Topological Spaces and Fundamental Group
- **Instructor:** Michael Hopkins
- **Overall Rating:** 4.52/5.0 (Higher than MATH 136)
- **Mean Hours per Week:** 10.8 hours (Almost double the workload of MATH 136)
- **Description:** Introduction to abstract topological spaces and algebraic topology including homotopy theory, fundamental groups and covering spaces.
- **Student Comments:** Varies from "Auroux is a great lecturer" to "This class is hard... stay far away [unless you're concentrating in math]."

### Lower-Level Options (Not 130s Level)

If you're considering lower-level options for the fall semester:

1. **MATH 19A - Modeling and Differential Equations for Life Sciences**
   - **Rating:** 4.55/5.0
   - No workload data available
   - More applied focus toward life sciences

2. **MATH 18A - Multivariable Calculus for Social Sciences**
   - **Rating:** 4.43/5.0
   - No workload data available
   - Note: Anti-requisite for MATH 21a, so you cannot take both

## Workload Comparison of 130s Courses

Here's how the 130s courses compare by workload:

| Course | Mean Hours | Q Score |
|--------|------------|---------|
| MATH 136 | 6.1 | 4.25 |
| MATH 137 | 10.0 | 4.28 |
| MATH 132 | 10.1 | 4.18 |
| MATH 130 | 10.3 | 2.00 |
| MATH 131 | 10.8 | 4.56 |

## Recommendation

**MATH 136 (Differential Geometry)** is clearly your best option if you're prioritizing a lighter workload while fulfilling your 130s requirement. With only 6.1 hours per week (compared to 10+ hours for other options), and a solid Q score of 4.25, it offers the best balance of quality and manageable time commitment.

If you're more concerned with course ratings than workload, MATH 131 has the highest rating (4.56), but requires nearly double the weekly time commitment at 10.8 hours.

Would you like more specific information about any of these courses?

# MATH 121 - Linear Algebra

I notice that you're asking for the course card for MATH 121, but according to your student profile, you've already taken this course. Nevertheless, here are the details:

## Course Details
- **Instructor:** John Cain
- **Term:** Spring 2026
- **Overall Rating:** 4.3/5.0 (which is considered good)
- **Mean Hours per Week:** Not available in the provided data

## Course Description
This is a second course in linear algebra, with an emphasis on understanding linear algebra at a more abstract level and learning to read and write proofs. Topics include:
- Real and complex vector spaces
- Linear transformations
- Eigenvalues and eigenvectors

## Requirements
Anti-requisite: Not to be taken in addition to Mathematics 22a, 23a, 25a, or 55a.

## Student Feedback
Students generally had positive things to say about the course:
- "Very open/exploratory course. You can tell that the instructor REALLY cares about students."
- "Take Math 121 :)"
- "If you take this course, be sure to hold yourself accountable. Because of its looser structure, it is easy to allow yourself to fall a bit behind."

Since you've already taken MATH 121, you might be looking for information on follow-up courses. Based on our previous conversation, MATH 136 (Differential Geometry) would be a good option for Fall 2025 to fulfill your 130s-level requirement with a relatively manageable workload of 6.1 hours per week.

Would you like more information about specific next steps after MATH 121, or was there something else you wanted to know about this course?

courseData.comments: ["Very open/exploratory course. you can tell that Dylan REALLY cares about his students. I walked away from the class learning more about my relationship with math and learning. The class could have been better with more structure but it was what I needed for the semester. It is a very easy going course","Take Math 121 :)","If you take this course, be sure to hold yourself accountable. Because of its looser structure, it is easy to allow yourself to fall a bit behind.","This class is what you make of it – you can do as much or as little as you like to get by. If you do wish to do more, it's certainly possible and can be a great mathematics course in this regard, especially with experience writing proofs.","This is a great intro to proofs! The topics are interesting, but I strongly recommend taking Math 21b beforehand.","This is a very difficult class that is very chill if you want it to be. ONLY take this class if you really want to learn math AND are VERY self–guided.","With Dylan Wilson, there is opportunity to explore if you have the time and motivation. There are no grades, which means that you have to be *really* self–driven to make the class what you want. I did not, and so I feel like I did not get much out of the class. I will be self–studying MIT's 18.06 Linear Algebra class to make up for my lack of foundational linear alg knowledge.\n\nWhen I tried to pset with peers, many politely declined because they valued the class as lower relative to their other classes. Thus, the lack of grading in this class RELATIVE to other classes means that there was a lack of community through struggle (lol). I wish I got to know my peers better!! They seemed like cool people.","This class is much more proof–based than something like Math 21b, and I would recommend having 21b under your belt beforehand, because without it, material in proof format can seem much more confusing. Dylan was great and super helpful, though not sure what this class under another professor would be like.","If you have any interest in upper level mathematics, you should take this class. It will give you all the necessary tools you need to pursue anything else you would choose to in the department.","If Dylan Wilson is teaching this class – take it. Best professor I've had in terms of actually prioritizing learning over completionism. The course material is still a little dry – it's proof–based linear algebra, but Dylan makes up for it.","Dylan is an AMAZING professor. I have never felt safe in a math classroom to inquire and genuinely learn until I took Dylan's class/had him as a professor. He really emphasizes learning to learn instead of for an output (grade). He is also great at explaining difficult concepts, and some things I didn't understand in 21b suddenly clicked in 121. Be wary of who is teaching this though––experience is highly dependent on the instructor.","This class has a ton of flexibility. If you can manage things on your own without outside structure, then take this class! Dylan is super nice and puts an emphasis on learning purely for learning's sake. If you're not great with a lot of flexibility and need external structure, don't take this. It's very self guided, so you won't be able to learn just with what's given.","Take this class; it will definitely expand your understanding in general beyond math.","It is probably not worth your time.","Great class"]

- Real and complex vector spaces
- Linear transformations
- Eigenvalues and eigenvectors

## Requirements
Anti-requisite: Not to be taken in addition to Mathematics 22a, 23a, 25a, or 55a.

## Student Feedback
- "Very open/exploratory course. You can tell that the instructor REALLY cares about students."
- "Take Math 121 :)"
- "If you take this course, be sure to hold yourself accountable. Because of its looser structure, it is easy to allow yourself to fall a bit behind."

Since you've already completed MATH 121, you might be interested in follow-up courses. As we discussed earlier, MATH 136 (Differential Geometry) would be a good option for Fall 2025 to fulfill your 130s-level requirement, with a relatively manageable workload of 6.1 hours per week compared to other 130s courses.

Is there something specific about MATH 121 you're trying to find out, or would you like information about other courses?
